entry.title: Explore the LA neighborhood that offers a slice of Japan
entry.summary:
It's easy to get lost in another culture while strolling through Little Tokyo, Los Angeles' main hub for Japanese culture. This Los Angeles neighbourhood is an enclave of mochi ball bakeries, manga bookshops and cool karaoke bars where you can sing your heart out.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Take a stroll through Little Tokyo, where red paper lanterns hang overhead and kids saunter by in cosplay outfits, and itâ€™s easy to feel like youâ€™re wandering the urban streets of Japan. But a second glance quickly reveals the telltale signs that youâ€™re in the US. Dodgers baseball caps dot the crowd, palm trees sway lazily in the warm breeze and grocery shops display mochi rice balls filled with creamy Southern Californian peanut butter. For all its fâ€¦

entry.title: Guide to Investigating Food Insecurity
entry.summary: This reporting guide is designed to help journalists understand the causes of food inequity, famine, and starvation as well as the global agencies and data sources tracking these phenomena.

entry.title: How food offers a rare window into Tennesseeâ€™s Amish Country
entry.summary:
Barns, silos and fields of oats are a common sight in the countryside of Tennessee, where the Amish run their community farms. The fertile backcountry of rural Tennessee offers a vital lifeline to the Amish, a deeply traditional community living apart from the modern world. join a Tour for a taste of life in this unique corner of the American South.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Amish are fond of a sweet treat, Fannie Yoder tells me as we wander the aisles of her delicatessen in Tennesseeâ€™s Amish Country. Sheâ€™s not kidding. Around us, shelves groan beneath glossy slabs of fudge. There are towers of cinnamon rolls, swirled high with thick peaks of icing. Stacks of sugared doughnuts and fried pies stretch to the far wall, oozing jam. â€œIt â€¦

entry.title: See a different side to Switzerland by rail
entry.summary:
Youâ€™ve got to hand it to the Swiss: they can do trains. Punctual and pristine, some of Europeâ€™s greatest railways chug through every inch of this ravishing land, stretching from the Alpine valleys of the Engadine to the vine-ribbed shores of Lake Geneva. One route â€” the 795-mile Grand Train Tour of Switzerland (see map, below) â€” brings together the countryâ€™s highlights. But beyond celebrated sights like the Matterhorn or Lake Lucerne, plenty of lesser-known treasures await â€” from pyramid peaks and crash-bang waterfalls, to sky-high vineyards and folksy villages. Read on for six fantastic rail stops up and down the country.
Can you hear thunder? Thatâ€™s the rumble and roar of the 500ft-wide Rhine Falls â€”Europeâ€™s largest cascades, tucked among the green pleats and forested folds of norâ€¦

entry.title: Love classic cars? These are the most retro road trips on Earth
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Nothing beats hitting the open road. Thereâ€™s something undeniably romantic about watching a destination roll by â€” all on your own schedule â€” and if youâ€™ve opted for a convertible, the age-old cliche of feeling â€˜the wind in your hairâ€™ can become an exhilarating reality.
Trend reports from the likes of Travelbag and Travel Tomorrow cite â€˜slow travelâ€™ as an enduring trend this year, where travellers take things a little more leisurely, focusing on the quality and depth of experiences rather than ticking off a list. Road trips are, perhaps, the ultimate way to slow down and take it all in, and what better way to do it than in a classic car?
According to Booking.comâ€™s Travel Reinvented report for 2025, meanwhile, â€˜â€¦

entry.title: Worldâ€™s oldest RNA found in woolly mammoth
entry.summary:
Yuka the woolly mammoth was exhibited in the Permafrost Kingdom museum in Yakutsk, Russia. These rare molecules provide insights into the final moments of the young mammothâ€™s life.
In 2010, tusk hunters scouring a riverbank near Siberiaâ€™s Arctic coast discovered the mummy of a juvenile mammoth. The animal, nicknamed â€œYukaâ€ after the nearby village of Yukagir, had been frozen for nearly 40,000 years. The permafrost preserved its carcass in exquisite detail, with patches of reddish fur, a twisted trunk and even its brain intact.
Now, researchers report that Yukaâ€™s tissues preserve another rare prehistoric treasure: traces of ribonucleic acid (RNA), genetic molecules that are crucial to life but usually deteriorate shortly after death. The teamâ€™s findings, published today in the â€¦

entry.title: Seattle is a city best explored via bike
entry.summary:
Pike Place Market has started a pilot program to make the streets more pedestrian- and bike-friendly by limiting cars. The Emerald City is home to a passionate pedaling culture and rife with well-protected, beautiful routes. Hereâ€™s your guide to Seattleâ€™s best bike paths, shops, and other cycling essentials.
Seattle is known for its lush natural landscapes, its coffee and food scene, its grunge music, the Space Needle, and Greyâ€™s Anatomy, but not everyone is aware of its enthusiastic cycling scene. In fact, during the 1890s, Seattle was among the first cities in the United States to construct dedicated bicycling infrastructure, laying out some 25 miles of pedal-friendly paths, and it has developed a thriving bike culture ever since.
Today, Seattle is home to a slew of stunningâ€¦

entry.title: Scientists found a way to reverse kidney damageâ€”is a cure next?
entry.summary:
A healthy human kidney like the one pictured here filters waste products from the blood. When the kidneys start to fail, there have historically been limited optionsâ€”until recently. An influx of chronic kidney disease treatments have proven that they can preserve kidney function, and in some cases, even improve it. Experts say weâ€™re in a golden age for treating chronic kidney disease, with new drugs like Ozempic yielding major results. Will dialysis and organ transplants become a thing of the past?
Nicolas Palacios got the bad news on his daughterâ€™s first birthday in July 2020. Palacios, who was 28 years old at the time, had lost his job a couple weeks earlier and was dealing with severe fatigue, which his doctor had called to tell him was in fact a symptom of Stage 4 kidney diseasâ€¦

entry.title: What happened when Vikings died? Elaborate funerals
entry.summary:
The first image that springs to mind when we think of Vikings may be that of an axe-raising, bearded raider, but behind all the blood and glory lies a culture still shrouded in mystery, especially when it comes to death.
For the Norse, the afterlife wasnâ€™t a single, unified place. It was made up of distinct spiritual otherworlds. Some warriors slain in battle went to dwell in Valhalla, or ValhoÌˆll in Old Norse, known as â€œthe hall of the slain.â€ Here, warriors fought and feasted endlessly while waiting to be called by the god Odin to RagnaroÌˆk, the catastrophic end of the world. Other warriors dwelled in Folkvangr, the â€œfield of the armyâ€ ruled by the goddess Freyja. The most commonly portrayed afterlife was that of Hel, a cold and misty underworld ruled by a goddess of the same name. â€¦

entry.title: Spainâ€™s Costa Blanca or Costa Brava: Which should you visit?
entry.summary:
Calpe Rock, off Costa Blanca's coast in Spain. Both boast sprawling beaches, fascinating traditions, and revered vineyards. Hereâ€™s how to plan your trip to either end of the Spanish Mediterranean.
By name alone, Valenciaâ€™s Costa Blanca and Cataloniaâ€™s Costa Brava sound like siblings, but their parallels donâ€™t stop there. With dramatic shorelines and historic villages, these Mediterranean regions reflect the wide-ranging appeal of Spainâ€™s eastern coast, which stretches for around 1,000 miles.
Nuances, however, materialize in each coastâ€™s cuisine, culture, and claims to fame. Below, youâ€™ll uncover the distinct reasons to visit Spainâ€™s southeast and northeast coastsâ€”both of which promise sprawling beaches and late-night dinners.
Alicante, Costa Blancaâ€™s capital city, earneâ€¦

entry.title: The medical mistakes that killed a U.S. president
entry.summary:
President James A. Garfield stands for a half-length portrait in Sarony, N.Y. In the summer of 1881, a gunshot at a Washington D.C. train station set off one of the most dramatic chapters in American historyâ€”the slow and gruesome death of the 20th president of the United States.
On July 2, 1881,Â United States presidentÂ James A. Garfield waited at Washington, D.C.â€™s Baltimore and Potomac Railroad Station to board a train that would take him to New England to begin his summer vacation and reunite with his wife.
The presidentâ€™s journey home took a deadly turn.Â Charles Guiteau, a disgruntled would-be federal worker, came up behind Garfield, pulled out a gun, and shot the president twice.Â
The bullets didnâ€™t initially killÂ Garfield. Instead, he experienced a slow, agonizing deâ€¦

entry.title: â€˜Mobsâ€™ target Palestinians in occupied West Bank, as floods roil Gaza
entry.summary: Images emerged this week of what appear to be mobs of masked Israeli settlers carrying out arson attacks on Palestinian homes and property, the UN human rights office (OHCHR) said on Friday.

entry.title: Security Council lays the ground in the race for the next Secretary-General
entry.summary: The UN Security Council met on Friday for its annual debate over how it operates â€“ including the process to select the next Secretary-General in 2026.

entry.title: Indigenous protesters block COP30 entrance, demand action from Brazilian Government
entry.summary: Around 90 Indigenous people from the Munduruku Indigenous group staged a peaceful protest early Friday, blocking the main entrance to the Blue Zone â€“ the restricted area set aside for negotiators â€“ at COP30 in BelÃ©m. Access was halted for about an hour, and the army was called in to reinforce security.

entry.title: Diabetes now affects 1 in 6 pregnancies: What you need to know
entry.summary: Diabetes is one of the worldâ€™s fastest-growing health challenges â€“ and its impact stretches across every life stage, from childhood to older age.

entry.title: COP30: Climate crisis is a health crisis, WHO warns as philanthropies pledge $300m for solutions
entry.summary: Climate change is already fueling a global health emergency, killing more than half a million people each year through extreme heat and threatening hospitals worldwide, according to a major report released on Friday at COP30 in BelÃ©m, Brazil.

entry.title: Stolen Past: Inside the fight against illicit antiquities trafficking
entry.summary: The illicit trade in cultural property is one of the worldâ€™s oldest and most profitable forms of criminal activity â€“ but now efforts by the UN and law enforcement agencies across the world are helping to bring down these global operations.

entry.title: Ukraine: UN condemns latest deadly attack targeting civilians in Kyiv
entry.summary: Several civilians were killed and many others injured, including children, in a large-scale Russian attack on Ukraineâ€™s capital and the wider Kyiv region early on Friday.

entry.title: Sudan war: Aid teams plead for access to thousands trapped in El Fasher
entry.summary: Just how many people are still trapped in the Sudanese city of El Fasher? Thatâ€™s the burning question for relatives of the many thousands of people believed to still be there, since paramilitary fighters overran the regional capital of North Darfur last month, after a 500-day siege.

entry.title: Zurichâ€™s most exquisite patisseriesâ€”in pictures
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
For more than two centuries, Switzerland has shaped the worldâ€™s idea of chocolate â€”Â velvety smooth, impeccably tempered and meticulously refined. In Zurich, a city steeped in history and tradition, the art of patisserie is approached with the same precision. Here, recipes vary from intricate cream-filled confections to crumbly tartlets crowned with lacquered fruit and meringue-based macarons no larger than a coin. Some are treasured family recipes, honed over the generations; others come from a new wave of patissiers blending bold flavours with elegant designs. Yet all convey a distinctly Swiss sensibility, one thatâ€™s driven by masterful craftsmanship and an unwavering eye for detail. undefined undefined Other tempting offerings include crumbly streusel cakes, croissants and seasonal pastries, all served on the first floor in a series of cosy salons with gilded mirrors, velvet chairs and dark wood panelling. Then, when the weather warms, travellers can retreat to the cafeâ€™s patio, shaded by red parasols and tucked behind leafy greenery. undefined undefined Published in the Luxury Collection 2025 by National Geographic Traveller (UK). To subscribe toÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK) magazine click here. (Available in select countries only).

entry.title: Data Cleaning Tools and Techniques for Non-Coders
entry.summary: Understanding, organizing, and validating data directly affects the accuracy of stories. New tools make cleaning accessible to journalists without coding.

entry.title: The truth about 3I/ATLAS
entry.summary:
The Hubble Space Telescope snapped this image of comet 3I/ATLAS, only the third interstellar object ever observed in our solar system. Scientists also used data from Hubble to estimate its size and speed.  Here's what we know â€”and don't knowâ€”about the interstellar visitor.
Back in July, scientists operating a planetary defense facility designed to detect potentially hazardous asteroids spotted a visitor from another star: an interstellar object, and the third of its kind ever discovered. The voyager, known as 3I/ATLAS, was only visible as a white pixelated splodge 420 million miles from Earth. At the time, very little was known about the object except that it was some sort of comet.
But over the summer, 3I/ATLAS plunged toward the inner solar systemâ€”and the fireworksâ€¦

entry.title: This virus infects almost everyoneâ€”and it may lead to lupus
entry.summary:
This colorized transmission electron micrograph shows Epsteinâ€“Barr virus (EBV). Nearly everyone carries this virus, which new research suggests may help set lupus in motion by altering key immune cells. Nearly all adults carry Epsteinâ€“Barr virusâ€”but new research reveals how it can hijack immune cells, sparking a chronic disease that attacks the body from within.
For decades, scientists have suspected that a common virus most people acquire in childhood may later trigger lupus, a chronic autoimmune disease capable of damaging nearly every organ system in the body. But the precise link has remained unclear.
Now, new research from Stanford University offers one of the clearest explanations yet.Â The findings show how the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can hijack the bodyâ€™s immune systemâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: Pew Research Centerâ€™s survey in South Africa was conducted as part of the Spring 2025 Global Attitudes Survey. The data is from a survey of 1,570 adults conducted face-to-face from Feb. 21 to March 30, 2025. Interviews were conducted in Afrikaans, English, North Sotho, South Sotho, Xhosa and Zulu. The survey is representative of the [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Laura Clancy, Research AnalystJordan Lippert, Research AnalystManolo Corichi, Research Analyst Julia Armeli, Research AssistantDorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerÂ Â Â Â Jonathan Evans, Senior ResearcherMoira Fagan, Research AssociateJanell Fetterolf, Senior ResearcherShannon Greenwood, [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. How South Africans view their countryâ€™s leaders, parties
entry.summary: As of early 2025, favorability of the governing African National Congress and optimism about the economy are both up since before the 2024 election. The post 2. How South Africans view their countryâ€™s leaders, parties appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. How South Africans see their countryâ€™s global standing
entry.summary: A plurality of South Africans say their countryâ€™s influence has been getting weaker in recent years, but views vary somewhat by political ideology. The post 1. How South Africans see their countryâ€™s global standing appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: South Africans See Their Countryâ€™s Influence Weakening Ahead of G20
entry.summary: Economic optimism remains low in South Africa but is improving. Adults there increasingly see China favorably and value economic ties with China. The post South Africans See Their Countryâ€™s Influence Weakening Ahead of G20 appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Tracking disease outbreaks to the ends of the Earth
entry.summary:
During an expedition to the Southern Ocean, microbial ecologist Jane Younger tests Antarctic marine life, including penguins, for bird flu to better understand how the pathogen is spreading around the continent and the globe. Climate change is speeding the spread of global pathogens. Can an early-warning system for animal viruses help stop pandemics before they start?
The ominous text arrived when National Geographic Explorer Jane Younger was aboard a research vessel in Antarcticaâ€™s Weddell Sea: â€œMore dead crabbies.â€ It was from a friend working as an expedition leader on a nearby cruise ship. He had spotted dead crabeater seals on the edge of the sea ice. Younger was studying how the bird flu sweeping the globe was circulating in the region, and the sightiâ€¦

entry.title: I took a ride on the most dangerous road in Vietnam
entry.summary:
A group of bikers riding down the famous nine-turn pass on Ha Giang Loop in northern Vietnam. â€œDoing the Loopâ€ is more than just a fad on social mediaâ€”itâ€™s a race through golden rice terraces, perilous mountain passes, and cloud-wrapped peaks.
Hands high in the air, I almost flew off my seat as Ly, my local driver, twisted around the edge of the cliffside. I had never felt more at peace than I did sitting on the back of his motorscooter, weaving between majestic mountains while driving the Ha Giang Loop, said to be the most dangerous road in Vietnam. Zipping by razor-sharp limestone cliffs, stairway-like golden rice terraces, and cavernous valleys, the thrill soothed my adrenaline junkie heart.
For a moment, everything levitated. My body floated above the hard plastic seat, thâ€¦

entry.title: Pair a pint with poetry at the UK's best book bars
entry.summary:
From the Cornish bookshop based in an 18th-century pub to the Glaswegian haunt offering artisanal cheese boards, here are some of the UKâ€™s top spots for bibliophiles. Far from mere bookstores, these outlets merge libraries, coffee lounges and cocktail bars into a one-stop-shop for bibliophiles.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
The traditional bookshop has been upgraded, with a new breed of alcoholic literary outlets serving up wine and cocktails alongside a curated collection of good reads. Taking a leaf from the New York trend, these cosy venues are springing up around London and across the rest of the UK. These outlets offer coffee, live music, author events, DJ sets â€” even literature-themed speed dating. Diversity is key, and unlike the quiâ€¦

entry.title: This island is the best place for stargazing in Spain
entry.summary:
Stargazers can witness the unparalleled beauty of the Milky Way and meteor showers, such as the Geminids, high above Teide National Park in Tenerife, Spain. Tenerife may be known for its beaches, but itâ€™s the islandâ€™s stargazing that leaves the biggest impression, boasting some of the clearest skies in the world.
Stargazing offers an immense sense of awe, a cosmic perspective of sorts. And few better places on Earth present that view more clearly than Tenerife. As Spainâ€™s most populous island, boasts aÂ year-round summer climateÂ and beaches that attract overÂ 6 million visitorsÂ annually. The islandâ€™s beauty is no secret, but when the sun sets and the beach crowds thin, another group emerges: amateur astronomers. Thanks to ideal atmospheric conditions, high visibility, and increased aâ€¦

entry.title: In 100 seconds, see the impact of humans on planet Earth
entry.summary:
A lone man walks across an expanse of ice; a mottled tundra; desert badlands. The single human figure becomes a focal point as images from Earthâ€™s diverse ecosystems change underfoot.Â
In this visual lies a metaphor: Human footprints have made their way across the entire planet, but how have they actually shaped the land?
That question drives Earth in 100 Seconds, a short film by geography educator and National Geographic Explorer Daniel Raven-Ellison. The project translates hard data on global land use into a storytelling device: a walk across the world, where each second represents one percent of Earthâ€™s land surface. The result reveals how more space is taken up by activities like ranching and farming than the parks and wild places that provide ample habitat for wildlife. â€¦

entry.title: The disappearing art of making great Champagne by hand
entry.summary:
Pablo Lopez strikes a match and lights a short white candle as he peers inside a bottle of one of the worldâ€™s most coveted Champagnes. He is standing alongside a row of wooden A-frame racks filled with several other bottles in a damp, dark medieval cellar in Reims, France; the chalk-walled gallery belongs to Maison Ruinart, one of the oldest Champagne houses in the region. Today itâ€™s also one of the few that still employ a traditional riddlerâ€”or remueurâ€”like Lopez, who is tasked with filtering the sparkling wine by hand.
Lopez holds up a bottle so that the candlelight shines through the glass, showing sediment suspended in the liquid.
â€œYou really need to understand the reading of the wines,â€ he says as he shakes the bottle to further loosen the dredge, an exercise called poigâ€¦

author.name: Stephanie Cain, CÃ©line Clanet, Fabrice Wagner

entry.title: Why hurricane flooding is about to get more dangerous
entry.summary:
A blue tang fish swims among coral at a site called Elbow Reef near Key Largo, Florida on November 29, 2023. A marine heat wave during the summer of that year rendered two Florida coral species "functionally extinct" according to a new paper. Floridaâ€™s coral reefs provide protection from hurricane storm surgesâ€”and experts estimate that losing key species in those reefs could imperil thousands of lives.
In July 2023, Katey Lesneski dove into the ocean off Key Largo to visit Horseshoe Reef, one of the largest and healthiest natural stands of elkhorn coral remaining in the region.
Normally, she wears a wetsuit to protect against the cold, but that day she didnâ€™t need oneâ€”the ocean was unusually warm. â€œThe water didnâ€™t feel refreshing,â€ she recalled.
As she peered through heâ€¦

entry.title: Earth always has more moons than you think
8 reasons to visit Valais, Switzerland
entry.summary:
If thereâ€™s an image of Switzerland more recognisable than the heirloom watches, chocolate bars and fondue sets, then itâ€™s the majestic Matterhorn, the iconic pyramidal peak located in Valais, a canton in the south west. This French- and German-speaking region abounds with mountains and glaciers, all easily explored on panoramic trains and ski lifts. Whether youâ€™re seeking adventure or relaxation, here are eight ways to enjoy the natural highs of Valais.
The Alpsâ€™ longest glacier is a wondrously eerie place for an adventure. The 14-mile ice flow is a ghostly presence, all exposed white ribs and shadowy crevasses. For the best views of the glacier, head to Bettmerhorn and Eggishorn; both viewpoints are accessible by cable-car from the village of Bettmeralp. Weighing 10 billion tonnes,â€¦

entry.title: From Haiti to Ethiopia: voices of climate displacement at COP30
entry.summary: Floods, heatwaves, droughts and storms are forcing millions from their homes every year. Most never cross a border; they remain internally displaced yet uprooted all the same. But experts warn that in the not-so-distant future, entire nations could disappear beneath rising seas or become uninhabitable through drought.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Typhoon generation, disability rights in Myanmar, new refugee-led climate fund
entry.summary: The strongest typhoonÂ to make landfall this year in the Philippines has impacted a staggering 1.7 million children â€“ and more than five million people overall.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Families in Sudan â€˜running out of timeâ€™ as hunger spreads
entry.summary: More than 21 million people in Sudan, 45 per cent of the population, are not getting enough to eat as the war between rival militaries continues, according to the World Food Programme (WFP).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ending UNWRA services would imperil political way forward: Lazzarini
entry.summary: Lack of sufficient funds is jeopardizing the ability of the UN relief agency for Palestine refugees (UNRWA) to operate, the head of the agency said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Protecting lives in a warming world: Health takes centre stage at COP30
entry.summary: Hailed by Brazil as â€œa crucial moment to demonstrate the strength of the health sector in global climate action,â€ a blueprint for global health systems to adapt to rising temperatures and extreme weather has been launched at the COP30 UN climate conference.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ethiopia: UN supports response to potentially deadly virus outbreak
entry.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is supporting Ethiopia as the country faces a suspected viral haemorraghic fever outbreak in the south, the UN agency said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: War has made children violent, sad and bereft
entry.summary: More than nine in 10 children in Gaza are displaying signs of aggressive behaviour linked to more than two years of war between Hamas and Israel, welfare agencies have reported.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Taste Sri Lanka's finest tea right at the source
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Sitting just south of Colombo, the Kalutara District has been characterised by agriculture for centuries. Lush green fields, so neatly hemmed they look sewn into the landscape by hand, roll across this area of southwestern Sri Lanka. It isnâ€™t long after leaving the capital city that youâ€™ll start to see women in colourful saris plucking tea leaves and dropping them into hessian sacks hung on their backs; men chiselling spirals into tall trees; and shirtless locals sitting cross-legged under shady canopies by the side of the road, shaving slender sticks with laser precision. These are Kalutaraâ€™s tea-pickers, rubber-tappers and cinnamon-peelers.
The fertile tropical soil, coupled with access to the Kalu Ganga river anâ€¦

entry.title: How to see the northern lightsâ€”and why theyâ€™re more common now
entry.summary:
The northern lights, or aurora borealis, hang above the fishing village of Reine on Norway's Lofoten archipelago. The best places to see this ethereal display are in "auroral zones" that are close to Earth's polesâ€”but sometimes you can see them from even farther north and south.

The aurora borealis and aurora australis have dazzled us in the night sky for centuries. Hereâ€™s what causes themâ€”and where the best places are to catch a glimpse. No matter how many times you see them, the northern lights, or aurora borealisâ€”and their Southern Hemisphere equivalent, the aurora australisâ€”are an ethereal, breathtaking sight. Dancing silently in Earthâ€™s upper atmosphere, they form iridescent sheets of green and red (or sometimes blue and purple) â€¦

entry.title: Appendix B: Post and comment classification prompts
entry.summary: For this report, Reddit posts and comments were classified using the following prompts to GPT-4.1 mini. The prompts were designed to mirror the codebooks that our research team used to create the validation datasets of human-annotated posts and comments. In the prompt templates below, italics indicate input text that varies based on the post or [â€¦] The post Appendix B: Post and comment classification prompts appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix A: Distinctive terms by topic in r/Parenting posts
entry.summary: All 29,925 Reddit posts in our dataset were classified by mentions of three topics: family finances, technology use, and division of labor. We used a pointwise mutual information (PMI) metric to identify terms that are associated with posts mentioning each topic. Distinctive terms for each topic are listed in the table below. The post Appendix A: Distinctive terms by topic in r/Parenting posts appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: This report is based on two different data sources: a representative survey of U.S. parents and Reddit data from the r/Parenting subreddit. The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 171 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals: Primary researchers Anna Lieb, Computational Social Science AssistantAthena Chapekis, Computational Social Science AnalystSono Shah, Associate Director, Data LabsAaron Smith, Director, Data LabsSofia Conway, Qualitative Analysis InternSawyer Reed, Research Assistant Research team Devin Teehan, Former Qualitative Analysis Intern Editorial and [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How Parents Use Online Communities
entry.summary: On Reddit's largest parenting forum, around one-in-five posts mention kids' tech use. Posts often express negative emotions, but comments are overwhelmingly supportive. The post How Parents Use Online Communities appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: The best places to eat in Mississippi may be at gas stations
entry.summary:
Fratesi's Grocery has been a staple of the Leland, Mississippi, community since it opened in 1941. From Delta tamales to â€œchicken on a stickâ€ in Oxford and spicy Vietnamese seafood boils along the Gulf, here are the roadside stations that serve up a taste of the stateâ€™s culture and history.
Stop at just about any gas station in Mississippi, and youâ€™ll be greeted with a full tank and an even fuller belly.
While most would associate gas station food with rows of chips and candy bars, a wall of sodas, and the questionable hot dog rotisserie, in Mississippi, youâ€™ll be met with jars of homemade jams, pickled veg, and a fully stocked kitchen with a chef slinging out fresh, delicious, hot food to a line of customers.
â€œI have long felt that you can learn a lot about a place by goâ€¦

entry.title: Can zapping your vagus nerve really ease anxiety?
entry.summary:
Vagus nerve stimulators deliver mild electrical pulses through the ear or neck, aiming to activate the bodyâ€™s built-in â€œrest and digestâ€ system. Researchers are investigating whether they can actually reduce stress and improve sleep. Vagus nerve stimulation is a social-media sensation, promising instant stress relief. Hereâ€™s what the science really says about the bodyâ€™s built-in â€œchillâ€ circuit.
Can you really calm your nervous system with a tiny jolt of electricity? Thatâ€™s the promise behind a new wave of wellness gadgets designed to stimulate the vagus nerve, which helps the body regulate stress, digestion, and mood. On social media, users say they are a â€œlife changerâ€ and that daily use helps them â€œsleep through the night,â€ and â€œget out of a panic attack in 20 seconds.â€
Â Thâ€¦

entry.title: Making sense of the pyramidsâ€™ enduring mysteries
entry.summary: So the pyramids might have been a kind of marine-industrial project, and what we now know as the sandblasted Giza plateau perhaps bordered a bustling harbor. It takes some getting used to. Those giant triangles in the desertâ€”at once confounding to modern adults and relatable to preschoolers everywhereâ€”have spawned so many crazy ideas that they long ago began to seem like primeval provocations. Some of this, including the persistent notion that these are alien deposits, was owed to the implausible sourcing and transport of so much raw material, hurdles that recede after the discovery of a lost branch of the Nile. But the pyramidsâ€™ final assembly instructions remain lost in the mail. We know only that they are uncannily aligned with the cardinal directions and that their bases are remarkablyâ€¦

entry.title: Exclusive: Sperm whale speech has human-like 'vowels'
entry.summary: A group of sperm whales (Physeter macrocephalus) swims together in the Indian Ocean. For years, researchers with Project CETI have worked to decode the communication of the species. The mammals' mysterious clicks contain a stunning level of complexity, a new study shows. Humpback whales sing songs with melodies so beautiful they lulled a generation of babies to sleep and sparked a global movement to save the whales from extinction. The sounds that sperm whales produce, however, are far less musical. They emit powerful staccato clicks that call to mind a thumbnail dragging over the teeth of a metal comb, or an underwater jackhammer. But what they lack in musicality they make up for in depth. Scientists are increasingly realizing that sperm whales have one of theâ€¦

entry.title: 6 coastal highlights of Spain's Costa de la Luz
entry.summary:
Cape Trafalgar is famous not just as the site of the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805, but also for its lighthouse. Whether youâ€™re cycling or riding, hiking or dining, the Costa de la Luz is awash with adventures.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
From wild Atlantic beaches to pine-clad cliffs and seafood feasts in the dunes, Spainâ€™s luminous Costa de la Luz is a region that rewards slow discovery. Shaped by history and nature, itâ€™s a place where tuna has been fished for millennia, wetlands echo with bird calls, and horses canter into blazing sunsets. Its contrasts are striking, its stories compelling â€” and these six highlights capture the coastâ€™s enduring allure.
For three millennia, Atlantic bluefin tuna has been fished in the bountiful watâ€¦

entry.title: UN and African Union vow closer action for peace and development
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General called on Wednesday for action to prioritize Africa, urging the world not to turn its back on the continent.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜A wave of truthâ€™: COP30 targets disinformation threat to climate action
entry.summary: Negotiators in BelÃ©m, Brazil, opened COP30 with a stark warning: the race to avert catastrophic global heating is being sabotaged by a surge of climate disinformation. The falsehoods, spreading faster than ever online, threaten to derail fragile progress on climate action.

entry.title: TB cases fall for first time since pandemic
entry.summary: Tuberculosis, or TB, remains one of the worldâ€™s deadliest infectious killers, claiming over 1.2 million lives and affecting an estimated 10.7 million people last year, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: At-risk mountain vipers and iguanas, in rare company at key wildlife talks
entry.summary: Renewed efforts to protect the worldâ€™s most exotic and endangered animals and plants from illegal traders, overexploitation and extinction are set to begin at UN-partnered biodiversity talks in Uzbekistan at the end of the month.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: Migration chief hears horrific accounts of exodus from El Fasher
entry.summary: Some 90,000 people have been displaced following the fall of El Fasher in Sudanâ€™s North Darfur - with another 50,000 fleeing violence in the Kordofans, according to the UN migration chief.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Gaza latest, Americas loses measles-free status, tornado recovery in Brazil
entry.summary: At least 600,000 litres of desperately needed diesel fuel has managed to enter the Gaza Strip in less than a week, UN aid coordinators OCHA said in an update.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukrainian civilian casualties rise 27 per cent compared to last year
entry.summary: Civilian casualties in Ukraine were 27 per cent higher from January to October 2025, compared to the same period last year, according to the latest UN human rights report on the situation in the eastern European country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Millions of lives at risk, warn UN food agencies, as hunger crisis worsens
entry.summary: The UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and World Food Programme (WFP) warn of a major hunger emergency, with acute food insecurity set to worsen in 16 countries and territories between now and May 2026, putting millions of lives at risk.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Latest deadly shipwreck highlights need for safer migration
entry.summary: Forty-two people are missing and presumed dead following a shipwreck off Libya â€“ the latest fatal crossing in the Central Mediterranean, where more than 1,000 lives have been lost this year.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Stand your ground: How one community in Brazil is coping with rising tides
entry.summary: For more than 40 years Ivanil lived in a house raised on stilts just 20 metres from the waterâ€™s edge, in the same community where she was born, on MarajÃ³ Island where the Amazon River meets the Atlantic Ocean in northern Brazil.

entry.title: The ultimate guide to Sonomaâ€™s wine country
entry.summary:
Sonomaâ€™s diverse microclimates make it ideal for growing over 60 grape varieties, establishing it as an exciting wine region in California. With bountiful organic produce, sustainable wineries and a glorious Pacific coastline, Sonoma county in northern California offers a beautiful, quieter alternative to its better-known neighbour, Napa Valley.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
An hour north of San Francisco, Sonomaâ€™s storybook landscape unfurls: mist-draped valleys, sun-dappled meadows and miles of Pacific coastline. Quaint towns with historic facades and artisanal shops whisper of a simpler, slower-paced era. Everywhere you turn, farm-fresh produce takes centre stage, from local markets to menus that celebrate the season. Yet beneath this idâ€¦

entry.title: 9 ways to experience classic Tanzania
entry.summary:
Despite the harsh conditions surrounding Lake Natron, about 2.5 million lesser flamingos come have adapted to feed on the algae found in the water. Best known for one of the worldâ€™s most incredible wildlife spectacles â€” the Great Migration across the Serengeti â€” this East African nation offers many extraordinary travel experiences, from mountain climbs to culture-rich stays on tropical islands.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Thereâ€™s much more to the central African nation than safari. Tanzania is a country that doesnâ€™t do things by halves. The big, bold, beautiful nation lays claim to Africaâ€™s highest mountain (Kilimanjaro) and its second-largest national park (Nyerere). It has portions of the continentâ€™s deepest and biggest lakes (Tanganâ€¦

entry.title: Where to hike without crowds near Grand Canyon
entry.summary:
Travelers visiting Grand Canyon National Park may want to consider visiting less-crowded places nearby, such as Glen Canyon National Recreation Area, which shares a border with the national park. Hike through secret slot canyons, spot endangered California condors, visit sacred Navajo sites, and kayak a stunning 10-mile section of the Colorado River.
In northern Arizona, near the Utah border, the community of Marble Canyon is surrounded by a distinct and stunning part of the Colorado Plateau. There are sheer, crimson-colored cliffs rising more than 3,000 feet, swirling sandstone slot canyons, and dramatic rock formations. A fraction of those who visitÂ Grand Canyon National ParkÂ make it to this remote and rugged region, essentially cut off from the rest of the state by the vast canyâ€¦

entry.title: Here are 10 of the most beautiful castles in Germany
entry.summary:
Neuschwanstein Castle, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is a 19th-century castle that is said to have inspired Disney. There are tens of thousands of castles in Germany. Here are ten of our favorites that you can visitâ€”or maybe even book as your very own fairy-tale wedding venue.
Germany is home to tens of thousands of castles, including one that is recognized the world over: Neuschwanstein was the inspiration for some of Disney's fairytale castles. The new National Geographic book,Â The Traveler's Atlas of the World, includes itineraries and recommendations for seeing castles, as well as what to do in countries all over the world. Here are 10 castles to visit in Germany.
This fairy-tale palace is so exquisite itâ€™s said to have inspired Disney theme park castles. Located souâ€¦

entry.title: Heavy drinking linked to deadlier brain hemorrhages
entry.summary:
A color-enhanced, cross-sectional CT image of the brain of a patient showing a massive intracerebral hemorrhage (bleed) in the right temporal lobe. New research shows a link between heavy drinking and bigger brain bleeds. A new study found that habitual drinkers were more likely to develop earlier strokes and larger brain bleeds.
Itâ€™s long been known that heavy drinking raises blood pressure and damages the liver. But new research suggests it may also deal a devastating blow to the brainâ€”causing life-threatening hemorrhagic strokes.
TheÂ study, published November 5 in Neurology,Â found that people who consumed three or more alcoholic drinks a day experienced bleeding strokes inside the brain an average of 11 years earlier than light or non-drinkersâ€”and faced worse outcomes such â€¦

entry.title: The students who developed a plan to stop Armageddon
entry.summary:
This spectacular image of comet Tempel 1 was taken 67 seconds after it obliterated NASA's Deep Impact's impactor spacecraft. In the 1960s, when the possibility of an asteroid impact alarmed the American public for the first time, MIT students drafted a blueprint for saving the Earth.
In 2021, a global survey of 10,000 young people between the ages of 16 and 25 found that 75 percent were fearful of the future. More than half believed that humanity is doomed to extinction.
Thereâ€™s good reason for such pessimism. Todayâ€™s college students are growing up in an era of rising and multiplying risks to humanity. But not all of these existential risks are growing more dangerous. In fact, the ultimate risk â€“ that of a world-destroying comet or asteroid impact â€“ is now much lower than it â€¦

entry.summary: At least 21 Rohingya refugees, including two teenage girls, have died after a boat carrying up to 70 people capsized in the Andaman Sea off the coasts of Malaysia and Thailand, according to UN agencies.

entry.title: Hurricane Melissa: Relief efforts intensify as damage across Caribbean grows
entry.summary: Two weeks after Hurricane Melissa tore through the Caribbean, governments and aid agencies are still struggling to reach communities left without homes, healthcare and basic services, as damage assessments in Cuba, Jamaica and Haiti continue to rise, the UN said on Tuesday.

entry.summary: Hundreds of protesters and others have been killed and an unknown number injured or detained in Tanzania following protests surrounding last monthâ€™s elections, according to reports obtained by the UN human rights office (OHCHR).

entry.title: Stakes rise for South Sudan: Whatâ€™s happening, and why it matters
entry.summary: South Sudan is entering a period of rising instability marked by political polarisation, renewed armed clashes, and severe humanitarian strain, senior UN officials told the Security Council on Tuesday.

entry.title: Keeping cool on a hotter planet: COP30 pushes for sustainable cooling and AI innovation
entry.summary: As the planet heats up, so does the race for smarter, cleaner technology. At COP30 in BelÃ©m, Brazil, delegates are weighing a paradox at the heart of climate innovation: how to harness powerful tools like artificial intelligence (AI) and advanced cooling systems without deepening the very crisis they aim to solve.

entry.summary: Fifty-two prisoners have died in Haitiâ€™s overcrowded prisons between July and September this year in conditions that have been described by the United Nations as â€œinhuman and degrading.â€

entry.summary: In war-torn Sudan, rape is likely being used as a weapon of war and simply being a woman there is â€œa strong predictorâ€ of hunger, violence and death, theÂ UNâ€™s gender equality agency warned on Tuesday.

entry.title: The model of catastrophe
entry.summary: The immense complexity of the climate makes it impossible to model accurately. Instead we must use uncertainty to our advantage - by David Stainforth Read on Aeon

entry.title: What is lake-effect snow?
entry.summary:
Steam is seen rising off a frozen Lake Michigan in Chicago. The Great Lakes region experiences a weather phenomenon called lake-effect snow, where cold, dry air passes over warmer lake water and forms bands of snowfall. Warmer waters are fueling stronger, snowier stormsâ€”at least for now. Hereâ€™s how scientists think this phenomenon will evolve as the planet gets hotter.
Winter weather is ransacking the Chicago metro area and parts of Indiana as the region experiences one of winterâ€™s most brutal weather phenomena: lake-effect snow. Heavy snow covered the area Sunday night into Monday morning, with more than a foot of snow recorded by mid-Monday.
Lake-effect snow forms when warm, unfrozen lake water and cold air meet. Some of the lake water evaporates into the air, making it warâ€¦

entry.title: Fossil eggs reveal new way to date the Age of the Dinosaurs
entry.summary:
Scientists excavate dinosaur egg nests in Mongolia's Eastern Gobi Basin. National Geographic Explorer Lindsay Zanno and her team analyzed eggs from the region to test a new method for dating fossils. Radioactive minerals in eggshells can help scientists pinpoint a fossilâ€™s age with stunning accuracy.
Eggs laid by dinosaurs have provided paleontologists with a new way to tell prehistoric time. By looking to radioactive minerals taken up by eggshells in the deep past, experts have uncovered a novel method to determine when those eggs were laidâ€”one that could put ancient ecosystems on a more accurate timeline
The new research, published today in the journal Communications Earth & Environment, adds to a growing body of evidence that fossil eggshells hold mineral clues that will alâ€¦

entry.title: The top outdoor experiences in El Salvador
entry.summary:
Dwarfed by volcano summits ever-looming on the horizon, El Salvadorâ€™s cloud forests flutter with the flight of iridescent birds. Its verdant hills level out at laid-back, black-sand beaches that line its Pacific shore, where surfers flock to the barrelling breakers. Opportunities for adventure far outstrip this Central American countryâ€™s small stature â€” despite its size, its landscape is diverse and densely packed with natural wonders.
The countryâ€™s cosmopolitan capital, San Salvador, is a convenient base for arranging adventurous excursions. From hiking up immense volcanos and swimming in the pools of hidden waterfalls, to paddling through mangrove forests brimming with wildlife and surfing world-class waves â€” here are the top outdoor experiences not to be missed. Spend a day oâ€¦

entry.title: Why Brussels is the perfect European city break
entry.summary:
Brusselsâ€™ skyline and Town Hall tower can be seen from the rooftop terrace of the Bourse Brussels building. Itâ€™s 30 years since daily Eurostar services began whisking visitors to Belgiumâ€™s capital â€” and the city known for Tintin and beer is still full of surprises.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With the exception of the â€˜Muscles from Brusselsâ€™ Jean-Claude Van Damme, itâ€™s a peculiar fact that none of the most famous Belgians are real. Tintinâ€™s a comic book creation; Poirot an invention of Agatha Christieâ€™s imagination; the tiny, blue Smurfs live in mushroom-shaped houses in a fictional forest. Belgiumâ€™s multilingual capital â€” and the de-facto home of the EU â€” is also known for its 400-year-old statue of a small boy peeing into a fountain. Leâ€¦

entry.title: The heroes who saved the world's last tigers
entry.summary:
This story originally published in the December 1997 issue ofÂ National GeographicÂ magazine.Â See more digitized stories from our archives here.
I first saw the tigress called Sita in 1986 in Bandhavgarh National Park in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh. She lay asleep on a hillside when the elephant I was sharing with the Indian naturalist Hashim Tyabji found her, full bellied after eating from the spotted deer that lay next to her. She was exhausted by the steady strain of having to feed and care for her first litter of three cubs, whose mewing I could just make out from still higher up the slope amid the expectant cawing of crows that teetered in the branches of the surrounding trees.Â
We were just 30 feet or so from the tigress, close enough to hear her steady, sonorâ€¦

entry.title: The first underwater photos reveal the ocean floor in full color
entry.summary:
Fish swim over a small head of brain coral and before massive Orbicella heads in one of the coral stacks, where small fish swarm during daylight hours only. Capturing the first underwater color photographs was no mean feat and involved powerful explosives as well as hours and hours of waiting.
This story originally published in the January 1927 issue ofÂ National GeographicÂ magazine.Â See more digitized stories from our archives here. The following illustrations are the first published natural color photographs made beneath the surface of the sea. They represent many weeks and months of experimentation by Dr. W. H. Longley, noted ichthyologist, of Goucher College, and Charles Martin, of the photographic laboratories of the National Geographic Society.Â
The conditions encounteâ€¦

author.name: National Geographic Staff, W. H. Longley, Charles Martin

entry.title: Why the mystery of the Edmund Fitzgerald endures
entry.summary: The S.S. Edmund Fitzgerald battles rough waters on her fateful voyage on Lake Superior in the artist David Conklin's painting, "Every Man Knew," commissioned to commemorate the anniversary of the tragic shipwreck. The Great Lakes freighter was one of the most technologically advanced of its time when it wrecked in Lake Superior 50 years ago. What went wrong? The good ship and crew were in peril. A savage storm was hurling hurricane-force winds, 35-foot waves, and blinding blasts of snow at the large freighter. Already reporting a â€œbad listâ€ with no radar and damaged ballast vents, it was taking on water and making slow progress battling its way across Lake Superior on November 10, 1975. Still, the vesselâ€™s skipper, Ernest M. McSorleyâ€”considered one of the best on the Grâ€¦

entry.title: What it really took to become an astronaut during the Space Race
entry.summary:
This story originally published in the January 1965 issue ofÂ National GeographicÂ magazine.Â See more digitized stories from our archives here.
This is the year of the Gemini.Â
Before 1965 is many months old, a powerful Titan II rocket will blast off from Cape Kennedy, carrying two American astronauts aboard a spacecraft called Geminiâ€”after the twins of the zodiac. For more than two years these men and their fellow astronauts have prepared themselves for Project Gemini and the epochal lunar voyages that will follow. They have pursued a unique training curriculum, and their classrooms lie scattered throughout the country.Â
They have attended hundreds of lectures, pored over thousands of documents, and sat through countless technical meetings.Â
They have conditioned their â€¦

entry.title: All about Evia, a stunning Greek island with few crowds
entry.summary:
Evia is the second-largest island in Greece, after Crete. Despite its size and proximity to the busy Greek capital, Evia is one of the least-known Greek islands, with healing baths, Venetian castles, and gorgeous scenery.
In Eviaâ€™s sylvan north, peaks clad with bright green pine trees soar above beaches where the water glows with emerald intensity. To the south, there are coves lapped by aquamarine seas. Can it sometimes take the pluck of a pirate to find them? Yes, but travelers undeterred by narrow roads and switchback curves will be richly rewarded.
â€œEvia offers an authentic slice of Greece that feels both timeless and undiscovered. Just a short drive or ferry from Athens, itâ€™s a land of lush mountains, thermal springs, unspoiled beaches, and charming villages where traditiâ€¦

entry.title: Why Norway should be your next family destination
entry.summary:
The FlÃ¥m Railway passes peaks, farms and waterfalls, making for a varied and exciting train journey for all ages. A natural playground, the fjord district is magical for families in winter. Visit now to catch the end of 2025â€™s strong aurora cycle.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With an abundance of fjords and mountains reachable by train, boat and on foot, outdoorsy families will find much to enjoy in this Nordic countryâ€™s western region â€” billed as â€˜Norway in a nutshellâ€™. Its superlative landscapes are ultra-accessible year-round and completely transformed by the seasons â€” visit in winter for snow and the Northern Lights, or summer for wild swims and glacier hikes.
Norwayâ€™s second largest city is the gateway to its fabled fjords. Strâ€¦

entry.title: Fossil eggs reveal new way to date the Age of the Dinosaurs
entry.summary:
Scientists excavate dinosaur egg nests in Mongolia's Eastern Gobi Basin. National Geographic Explorer Lindsay Zanno and her team analyzed eggs from the region to test a new method for dating fossils. Radioactive minerals in eggshells can help scientists pinpoint a fossilâ€™s age with stunning accuracy.
Eggs laid by dinosaurs have provided paleontologists with a new way to tell prehistoric time. By looking to radioactive minerals taken up by eggshells in the deep past, experts have uncovered a novel method to determine when those eggs were laidâ€”one that could put ancient ecosystems on a more accurate timeline
The new research, published today in the journal Communications Earth & Environment, adds to a growing body of evidence that fossil eggshells hold mineral clues that will alâ€¦

entry.title: Discover the wild side of Dubai with these thrilling adventures
entry.summary:
From vertical-acceleration roller coasters to skydives over manmade wonders, Dubai is awash with thrilling adventures. Whether youâ€™re heading for its desert, city, beaches or extraordinary artificial islands, the Gulf regionâ€™s most popular stopover is packed with pulse-quickening pursuits to spice up any fly-and-flop. Here are half a dozen to get you started.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Dubai has never been somewhere that does things half-heartedly. Highest, longest, deepest â€”Â the superlatives are pursued with a breathless urgency, creating the framework for whatâ€™s fast emerging as one of the worldâ€™s great playgrounds for thrill-seekers. From vertical-acceleration roller coasters to skydives over manmade wonders, freediving in the Marianaâ€¦

entry.title: Safeguarding clean water access as climate threats rise
entry.summary: As health emergencies multiply linked to the climate crisis, governments are joining forces with the UN to protect access to clean water, while data indicates that 118 million people in Europe alone live near healthcare facilities lacking basic sanitation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: How farms are spearheading a Northern Irish food revolution
entry.summary:
The Titanic Museum and Belfast Harbour are some of the county's major draws. In the backcountry around Belfast and the Causeway Coast, Northern Irish producers are bringing new life to old farms and creating community hubs that showcase the regionâ€™s rich artisan food scene.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Itâ€™s 11am and Iâ€™m having coffee. But as this is a â€˜Belfast coffeeâ€™, itâ€™s a cream-topped cold brew laced with a shot of poitÃ­n, served at the capital cityâ€™s snug-boothed 19th-century Garrick pub. â€œItâ€™s the sort of thing you used to get from your backcountry man,â€ says my jovial guide, Ali McDevitt, brushing cream from his whiskers. Irelandâ€™s moonshine, poitÃ­n, was outlawed in the 1600s, but people continued to make the unaged spirit at home â€¦

entry.title: Why you should visit Spainâ€™s lesser-known Costa de la Luz
entry.summary:
Vejer de la Frontera in Costa de la Luz is particularly striking at sunset, with sunlight glinting off its whitewashed houses. Forget what you think you know about the built-up Spanish Costas. The aptly named Costa de la Luz â€” or â€˜Coast of Lightâ€™ â€” is a quiet stretch along AndalucÃ­a's lesser-visited Atlantic seaboard, where rolling dunes meet pine forests and timeworn towns bask in the sun. Explore its natural parks and windswept beaches, bedding down in exclusive retreats along the way.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The coastal plain far below is enveloped in a shadowy slumber as dawn strikes the hilltop town of Vejer de la Frontera. The first rays of the day glance off the tiled fountain in Plaza de EspaÃ±a and provoke the sparrows in the â€¦

entry.title: James Watson dies at 97
entry.summary:
James Watson, the American 1962Â Nobel Prizeâ€”winning molecular biologist whose co-discovery of the double-helix structure of DNA helped make possible the mapping of the human genome, has died at age 97.
Often celebrated as a pioneer of genetics, allegations of uncredited work and discriminatory and inflammatory remarks cast a shadow over his legacy. James Watson (left) and Francis Crick (right) with their model of part of a DNA molecule in the Cavendish Laboratory at the University of Cambridge, UK, in May of 1953. Watson and Crick met at Cambridge in 1951 and are credited as the discoverers of the structure of DNA. Watson, Crick, and Maurice Wilkins shared the 1962 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine. Francis Crick(left) and James Watson (right) shortly after working out theâ€¦

entry.title: How to spend the perfect day in Shanghai, China's rapidly transforming megacity
entry.summary:
Penicillin bar on Nanchang Road makes inventive cocktails using recycled waste ingredients. From xiaolongbao dumpling kiosks to riverside beer emporiums and glamorous rooftop cocktail bars, this Chinese megacity offers travellers 24/7 entertainment.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Cut a dash through this Chinese megacity from the sycamore-shaded, heritage shopping streets of the former French Concession to the high-wattage urban wonderland of the Bund. Locals here work hard and play harder, so the energy is intense â€” and the people-watching is second to none.
Early birds get first crack at jianbing, the savoury crepes made with spring onions or chilli sauce at kiosks around town. Stroll along Changle Road in the former French Concessioâ€¦

entry.title: Sheâ€™s 86. This is her 1000th skydive. Hereâ€™s how she stays young.
entry.summary:
86-year-old Kim Knor completes her 1,000th jump in New Wales, Florida, alongside her two daughters. Knor was a member of the first U.S. Womenâ€™s Parachute Team in 1962. After taking a few decades off to raise her family, she has made it a mission to hit this milestoneâ€”earning the nickname the "skydiving grandma." Kim Knor has the kind of biography Hollywood blockbusters are made ofâ€”and has just notched a new milestone in her quest to keep living life to the fullest.
To many, sheâ€™s known as the â€œskydiving grandma.â€ And on Thursday, November 6, 2025, Kim Knor, also joined the ranks of those who have earned the United States Parachute Association Gold Wings Award for making 1000 jumps.Â
This 86-year-old powerhouse has been traveling the country in her 21-foot Roadtrek motor home iâ€¦

entry.title: Rats wage war on bats in stunning new footage
entry.summary:
A rat attacks a bat as it flies by in this still image from a video that researchers captured. New videos reveal the surprising dynamics of bat-rat relationshipsâ€”and suggest how human activity is fueling these interspecies conflicts.
In a dark cave in northern Germany, an invasive brown rat stands upright, balancing with its tail. Suddenly it reaches into the night sky, plucks a bat from the air, and crunches down on it.Â
At first,Â Mirjam KnÃ¶rnschildÂ was shocked by the scene, captured with infrared surveillance video as part of her research. KnÃ¶rnschild, head of the Behavioral Ecology and Bioacoustics Lab at the Museum of Natural History in Berlin, thought it could be an isolated incidentâ€”until her investigation at another German bat cave turned up more macabre evidence.Â â€¦

entry.title: What to do in Goudaâ€”and where to eat the best cheese
entry.summary:
Today, the Goudse Waag is home to the Cheese and Crafts Museum in Gouda, Holland. Hereâ€™s everywhere you should buy, taste, and learn about cheese in this historic small town in the Netherlands.
A medieval battle in Holland forever changed the cheese world as know it: Which city would be named the trading center for Stolse, what we know now as Gouda.
Gouda is and was made at dairy farms all throughout South Holland, so any city in the area could have been its trading center. Until 1412, Gouda cheese was called Stolkse (sweet milk) cheese and sold in the town of Stolwijk before moving to Schoonhoven.
Around 1540, the city of Gouda won the official cheese market title that it still holds today. Centuries later, cows still live in the lush meadows surrounding Gouda in the Cheâ€¦

entry.title: These towns in Nashville's backyard are luring travelers
entry.summary:
Travelers looking to explore beyond Nashville, Tennessee, should consider nearby small towns: Franklin and Leiperâ€™s Fork. Even country music stars are catching on to the appeal of Leiperâ€™s Fork and Franklin, with their intimate venues, rolling hills, and front-porch communities.
Twenty miles south of Nashvilleâ€™s neon signs, two Tennessee towns have been quietly attracting celebrities and country music stars like Chris Stapleton and Carrie Underwood. Franklin charms with its 19th-century downtown dotted with Southern boutiques, sophisticated dining, and Civil War sites. Nine miles west, the village of Leiperâ€™s Fork landed on the National Register of Historic Places for its â€œfolk vernacularâ€ architecture, which includes simple structures authentic to this rural region.Â
This smaâ€¦

entry.title: The art at these hotels rivals the worldâ€™s best museums
entry.summary:
Located in the heart of ancient Athens, The Dolli overlooks the Roman Agora. Enjoy Picasso over morning coffee, Dali over dinner, or take a garden stroll past a Henry Moore sculpture in one of these curated stays.
For anyone whoâ€™s ever felt disappointed after standing in a long museum queue only to peer over a sea of heads at a famous painting, hereâ€™s a bit of good news: A growing number of hotels and resorts around the world have begun showcasing world-class art collections without the lines or velvet ropes.
Guests or afternoon visitors can book a guided tour, scan QR codes to learn more about a piece, attend rotating exhibit openings, or just have a coffee and gaze at a favorite painting, says Kelly Cahn, a New York-based art advisor and appraiser who has worked with hotels.â€¦

entry.title: Medieval nostalgia is everywhere right now
entry.summary:
In 2024, Gen Z pop star Chappell Roan capped off her meteoric rise to fame with an MTV Video Music Awards performance of her hit single â€œGood Luck, Babe.â€ Equal parts playful and camp, Roan wore a suit of chainmail and gleaming plate armor and fired a crossbow to ignite a pyrotechnic display in a backdrop dominated by a digitally rendered castle. There was little in the song itself to prompt such iconography: the catchy pop hit is a sarcastic kiss-off from one woman to another who just canâ€™t admit their romantic relationship.Â
But Roan was paying homage to the long history of Joan of Arc, the patron saint of France, whoÂ has becomeÂ aÂ modern-dayÂ queer icon for transgressing gender norms when she tookÂ up arms to fight on her countryâ€™s behalf. Roan was drawing on the resonance between theâ€¦

entry.title: The mystery woman at the heart of Beethovenâ€™s secret love affair
entry.summary:
Ludwig van Beethoven appeared to be as unsuccessful in love as he was successful in music.
When the celebrated composer died on March 26, 1827, he left no widow to mourn himâ€”just an adoring public who lined the streets to catch a glimpse of his funeral procession.
But when Beethovenâ€™s secretary Anton Schindler went through his late employerâ€™s desk, he made a discovery that kickstarted one of music historyâ€™s most romantic mysteries.
Inside the desk was a yearning, passionate, and lyrical love letter that Beethoven seemed to have never sent. Beethoven did not name his intended recipient. Instead, he referred to her as his â€œImmortal Beloved.â€ â€œI can live only wholly with you or not at all,â€ he wrote, â€œyes, I am resolved to wander so long away from you until I can fly to your arâ€¦

entry.title: How one torpedo sank the mighty Lusitania
entry.summary:
Built between 1904 and 1906, R.M.S. Lusitania measured a whopping 787 feet in length and could accommodate over 2,000 passengers and 800 crew members. It soon became the flagship of its operator, the Cunard Line, and for a time was distinguished as being the largest passenger ship in the world. Both the vesselâ€™s luxurious design and fate are often compared to those of R.M.S. Titanic, launched in 1912 by Cunardâ€™s main rival, the White Star Line. Despite their grandeur, both ships met tragic ends, though under markedly different circumstances. While the Titanic sank after hitting an iceberg in 1912, the Lusitania was torpedoed by a German U-boat during the First World War.
Since the onset of WWI in 1914, Germany had faced a comprehensive naval blockade imposed by the British Navy thatâ€¦

entry.title: World News in Brief: Russian rights abuses in Ukraine, US a no-show for rights review, Orlando Blooms highlights Rohingya plight
entry.summary: Independent UN human rights investigators have heard first-hand accounts of torture, unlawful detention and the forced transfer of civilians during their first visit to Ukraine in more than a year.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Worrying reportsâ€™ continue of abductions and disappearances in Syria
entry.summary: Nearly 100 people in Syria have been abducted or forcibly disappeared since January, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said on Friday, calling for greater accountability from the authorities.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo hunger crisis worsening amid fighting and lack of aid funding
entry.summary: The crisis in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) continues to worsen amid ongoing fighting that has driven tens of thousands of people from their homes and created acute hunger, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Friday.

entry.title: 10 of Portugalâ€™s best secret beaches
entry.summary:
Whether you're looking for towering rock formations, reliable wildlife sightings or just sun, sea and silence, thereâ€™s a stretch of Portuguese sand for you. Head south to the Algarve for a smugglerâ€™s former haunt, or visit the west coast for Jurassic prints embedded into the cliffs â€“ these are some of the best crowd-free beaches.
Best for: spotting eagles and dolphins Lisbon isnâ€™t far from ArrÃ¡bida Natural Park, but youâ€™d never guess. With secluded coves and turquoise bays strung between forested hills, this nature park is home to some of Europeâ€™s most ravishing beaches. One of the loveliest is this crescent of creamy sand. The fact that you reach it via a steep, craggy path or by scrambling over rocks from neighbouring Praia de Galapos keeps things quiet, particularly if you avoid â€¦

entry.title: The fish crime detectives who protected the seas
entry.summary:
Indonesia routinely blew up vessels caught illegally fishing in their waters, like this one in 2017. Indonesia is particularly vulnerable to poachers who threaten their fishing stock and the health of the worldâ€™s oceans. The world needed a team of international police dedicated to fighting illegal fishing. Now, the group's gone quiet.
In the rough waves of the South Atlantic in February 2016, an Argentine coast guard ship approached a squid-jigging vessel illegally fishing inside the nationâ€™s territorial waters. As the Argentines approached, the boat winched its equipment aboard and quickly fled north. The Argentines ordered the boat to stop and then fired a warning shot, but it escaped across the watery border with Uruguay and headed into international waters. Before it disappeareâ€¦

entry.title: These overlooked muscles are the key to aging well
entry.summary:
Exercises like the plank train the bodyâ€™s full coreâ€”the network of muscles that protect the spine, support balance, and keep you moving strong for life. From the diaphragm to the pelvic floor, scientists say improving your core strength can protect your spine and help you move with ease into older age.
â€œSix-packâ€ abs might look like a sign of fitness, but they reveal surprisingly little about your health. The true secret to healthy aging lies not in visible abdominal muscles, but in the intricate network of muscles that make up your core.
These deeper core muscles stabilize your spine, protect your back, and power almost every movement you make. Yet training with standard moves like crunches for the sake of visible abs can do more harm than good, says Ben Yamuder, an exercise â€¦

entry.title: How one catastrophic shipwreck sank a medieval dynasty
entry.summary:
King Henry I's only legitimate heir, William Adelin, orders rowers to turn back and save his sister, the Countess of Perche, after the White Ship hit a rock in the Seine estuary. William died as the boat sunk due to the numbers struggling for survival. When a royal vessel sank of the coast of Normandy in 1120, it not only claimed hundreds of lives but also set off a succession crisis that changed England forever.
It should have been aÂ fairly routineÂ English Channel crossing for the boisterous and boozy crowd of young nobles aboard the White Shipâ€”a party that included William Adelin, sole legitimate male heir to King Henry I of England.
Only it all went horribly wrong as the ship embarked fromÂ Barfleur, in present day France, on November 25, 1120. The crew rowed right onto â€¦

entry.title: What it's like to climb Tanzania's Mount Kilimanjaro
entry.summary:
Trekking up the lower slopes of Kilimanjaro is an adventure that takes hikers to the highest peak of the continent. Kilimanjaro is a tantalising prospect: an enormous, continent-topping high that even ordinary hikers can reach once steeled to the task.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Terror and awe. Thatâ€™s how I feel on first glimpsing Africaâ€™s highest mountain. It fills the aircraft window, an incredible hulk of a thing. A brooding inevitability. It takes an age to fly past. Has my fear slowed time or is it really that big? When the massive massif is finally out of sight, itâ€™s still all I can see in my head, all I can think about.
Iâ€™m flying into Tanzaniaâ€™s Kilimanjaro Airport to climb that very peak, a 19,340ft behemoth that looms largâ€¦

entry.title: The best coastal road trip youâ€™ve never heard of
entry.summary:
Cave Point County Park is home to underwater caves and incredible sunrises. The â€œCape Cod of the Midwestâ€ is filled with memorable towns, delightful quirks, and incredible scenery. So why have so many people never heard of it? 
Door County, Wisconsin, is one of those blindsiding destinations that feels surprisingly hidden in plain sight; the kind of place where stunned travelers wonder how they had never heard of it before. The "Cape Cod of the Midwest" is more than just legendary Lake Michigan beachfrontsÂ andÂ four vibrant seasons.
TheÂ DoorÂ Peninsula is also filled with unique towns and offbeat attractions, making it perfect for aimless road trips where itineraries are best kept minimal.
(Why Oklahomaâ€™s Route 66 is the ultimate American road trip for 2026)
Stuâ€¦

entry.title: Farmers in Brazil are restoring biodiversity to grow resilient crops
entry.summary: Brazil is one of Earthâ€™s ground zeroes for climate change. Itâ€™s home to the Amazon, the worldâ€™s largest and most diverse tropical rainforest, which scientists have called the â€œlungs of the planetâ€ because it absorbs and stores global carbon emissions. But alarming amounts of the Amazon have been cleared and deforested over the last decades to make room for agriculture, exacerbating climate change. In a cyclical pattern, the agricultural landscape in Brazil, the worldâ€™s largest producer of staple crops, including soybeans and corn, is becoming increasingly challenged due to the impacts of a changing climate. This is especially true in the Cerrado region, which borders the Amazon and produces nearly half of the countryâ€™s agricultural products. Here, rainy seasons are beginning later and dry â€¦

entry.title: Appendix: Detailed tables on Americans ages 65 and older, by demographic group
entry.summary: The post Appendix: Detailed tables on Americans ages 65 and older, by demographic group appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 178 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted Sept. 2-8, 2025. A total of 8,750 panelists responded out of 9,928 who were sampled, for a survey-level response [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at pewresearch.org/topic/generations-age/age/older-adults-aging/ Kim Parker, Director of Social Trends ResearchJuliana Horowitz, Senior Associate Director, ResearchÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Rachel Minkin, Senior ResearcherLuona Lin, Research AssociateKiley Hurst, Research AnalystÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Dana Braga, Research AnalystBlen Wondimu, Research Assistant Reem Nadeem, Digital ProducerÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â John Carlo Mandapat, [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Whoâ€™s had plastic surgery or taken other measures to look younger?
entry.summary: As part of a survey aimed at understanding how Americans are thinking about and experiencing aging, we asked people if they have ever done or would consider doing each of the following to look younger than they are: Key takeaways: Itâ€™s important to note that we asked specifically if people have done or would consider [â€¦] The post Whoâ€™s had plastic surgery or taken other measures to look younger? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Experiences with estate planning and discussing end-of-life preferences
entry.summary: As part of our survey aimed at understanding how Americans are thinking about and experiencing aging, we asked U.S. adults some questions to learn: The survey of 8,750 U.S. adults was conducted Sept. 2-8, 2025. Read key findings from the full study. Who has done estate planning About three-in-ten U.S. adults say they have created: [â€¦] The post Experiences with estate planning and discussing end-of-life preferences appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Advice on aging from older Americans
entry.summary: As part of a survey of 8,750 U.S. adults aimed at understanding how Americans are thinking about and experiencing aging, we asked 2,582 Americans ages 65 and older the following question: â€œBased on your own experiences, what advice would you give to younger people to help them prepare for getting older?â€ Respondents answered this question [â€¦] The post Advice on aging from older Americans appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How Americans are feeling about their finances as they age
entry.summary: Amid a dwindling Social Security retirement trust and increased national life expectancy, many Americans are uncertain about their financial future. Four-in-ten U.S. adults say they arenâ€™t confident theyâ€™ll have enough income and assets to last throughout their retirement years or say they wonâ€™t be able to retire at all. Only about a quarter (26%) are [â€¦] The post How Americans are feeling about their finances as they age appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Aging well: How income and health shape the experiences of older Americans
entry.summary: About one-in-five adults in the U.S. today (18%) are ages 65 and older. To understand how these older Americans are aging and the factors associated with aging well, we asked them a series of questions about how things are going in their lives and how they spend their time. These questions are part of a [â€¦] The post Aging well: How income and health shape the experiences of older Americans appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How Americans Are Thinking About Aging
entry.summary: From how well they think theyâ€™re aging to how they rate their physical and mental health and financial security, older adults with upper incomes are doing better than those with middle or lower incomes. The post How Americans Are Thinking About Aging appeared first on Pew Research Center.
